title: Arman Daniel Catterson [website version]
text: I teach statistics and psychology at Diablo Valley College (as a professor with my own office and health insurance and tenure) and UC Berkeley (as a continuing lecturer who is not required to attend meetings or serve on committees). Thank you for visiting my webpage.

title: Arman Daniel Catterson [website version]
text:
Wave hi if you see me on campus
Talk to me after class
E-mail me using the address in our course syllabus.

Professor | Arman Daniel Catterson, PhD [he / his / ÿßŸà ] üê±(catterson@berkeley.edu)

Lectures : Fridays 9:00 - 12:00 PM in 1213 Berkeley Way West
Office Hours : Mondays 10:30 - 11:30 AM on Zoom (e-mail / chat after class to find another time)

Teaching Assistant | Sierra Semko Krouse [she / her] | sierra_semko@berkeley.edu

Sections : Fridays, 1:00 - 2:00 PM in 1213 Berkeley Way West
Office Hours : Wednesdays 2:00 - 3:00 PM via Zoom (click here to sign-up for a 15-minute slot)

Grade Details. Your grade in the class will be based on the following components. (Letter grades will be based on the following : A+ is > 96.5; A is > 92.5; A- is > 89.5; etc. Note that an 89.49999 is a B+.)









10% Attendance
30% R Exams [10 + 20]
10% Article Presentations


20% Lab Assignments
20% Final Project
10% Article Discussions

title: Psych 205 - Lab 1
text:
The goal of this lab is to get more practice working in R and R Markdown, and practice loading (and evaluating) datasets.


We will work on these questions together in lecture.

Define a variable














Look over the supplemental readings for instructions on how to load a dataset from a .csv file. Load each of the four datasets posted to our ‚ÄúDatasets‚Äù folder.

title: Psych 205 - Lab 1
text:
We will work on these questions together in lecture.

Define a variable

title: Psych 205 - Lab 1
text: Look over the supplemental readings for instructions on how to load a dataset from a .csv file. Load each of the four datasets posted to our ‚ÄúDatasets‚Äù folder.

title: Psych 205 - Lab 1
text:
The goal of this lab is to get more practice working in R and Quarto, and practice loading (and evaluating) datasets.


We will work on these questions together in lecture!

One advantage of R Markdown is that you can run code in a document. You do this using a ‚Äúcode block‚Äù. Enter in a math equation that used to give you difficulty as a kid to the code block below, and run the code to see the result.


In the space below, insert an R code block, and define a numeric variable in this code block.
In class, we will build a dataframe. Create that dataframe here, and use R code to answer the following questions.

the number of individuals (rows) in the dataset.
the number of variables (columns) in the dataset.
the names of the variables in the dataset.
the value of the 5th row, 2nd column in the dataset.
print a numeric variable from the dataset
print a categorical variable from the dataset



R also has some built in datasets. The chickwts dataset contains data on the weights of chickens, and the types of food that they ate. You can access this datasets by just typing chickwts (the name of the data object) into R. Use this dataset to answer the following questions:

the number of individuals (rows) in the dataset.
the number of variables (columns) in the dataset.
the names of the variables in the dataset.
the value of the 5th row, 2nd column in the dataset.
print a numeric variable from the dataset
print a categorical variable from the dataset





You will work with your TA on these questions.

In lecture, we created a dataframe in R with two variables. Work with your classmates to create another dataframe with three variables - at least one numeric and one ‚Äústring‚Äù. Then, use R to report the following from this dataset:

the number of individuals (rows) in the dataset.
the number of variables (columns) in the dataset.
the names of the variables in the dataset.
the value of the 5th row, 2nd column in the dataset.
print a numeric variable from the dataset
print a categorical variable from the dataset

In lecture, we wrote a for-loop to simulate the ‚ÄúMonty Hall‚Äù problem. Adapt this for-loop such that there are 100 doors (where the contestant chooses one, then Monty opens 98 other doors.) Under these conditions, what is the probability of winning if you switch? If you don‚Äôt switch?




Please try to complete these problems on your own after section. If you get stuck, post to the class ‚Äúdiscord‚Äù (and feel free to help others.) If you really get stuck, just explain what you tried. Thanks!

Look over the supplemental readings for instructions on how to load and navigate a dataset into R from a .csv file. Load each of the three datasets posted to our ‚ÄúDatasets‚Äù folder (make sure to give the dataset a name; check the headers, and set stringsAsFactors = T). For each dataset, use R to report the following statistics:

the number of individuals (rows) in the dataset.
the number of variables (columns) in the dataset.
the names of the variables in the dataset.
the value of the 5th row, 2nd column in the dataset.
print a numeric variable from the dataset
print a categorical variable from the dataset

Read the article ‚ÄúData Organization in Spreadsheets‚Äù posted to the course website. Choose one of the datasets uploaded to the Datasets folder, and look over the dataset (and corresponding Data Dictionary). What are some ways that this dataset adhered to these ‚Äúbest practices‚Äù? What are some ways that the dataset did not? What is something from this article that you learned? What did you have a question about?
Challenge Problem1. Quarto (and Markdown) can also be used to make a website. Make yourself a personal website, and use one of the methods to host this [I like github.] Yeah!

title: Welcome to Psych 205
text:
Introductions to the course, professor, and students.
Introductions to statistics.
Introductions to the program R.




Why is this class required?










The console is where R does its work.
Look at the image below.

What do you see?
What makes sense / what seems confusing?







In this class, I‚Äôll be using RStudio. RStudio is an IDE (Integrated Development Environment) that includes the console along with other useful windows and tools.

The Console is at the bottom left of the IDE. Hi console!
The R script is at the top left of the IDE, and is a document that you use to write (and organize) code. You will want to do most of your work in the R script, and feel an appropriate level of anxiety when you notice that your Rscript is unsaved (as indicated by the red text and *).
The Environment is at the top right of the IDE, and shows you all of the ‚Äúobjects‚Äù that you have defined in R.
The File Window is at the bottom right of the IDE, and shows you the files. Note that there are tabs here for Plots (where graphs will pop up), Packages (things you can download to give R extra features), a Help viewer (sometimes very useful!).
